textLatin: Cattle die, kinsmen die, the self must also die. I know one thing which never dies: the reputation of each dead man.
author: Hávamál, Stanza 77

textLatin: Not all those who wander are lost.
author: J.R.R. Tolkien

textLatin: Even the smallest person can change the course of the future.
author: Galadriel

textLatin: All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us.
author: Gandalf

textLatin: The only way out is through.
author: Robert Frost

textLatin: Fortune favors the bold.
author: Virgil

textLatin: Better to fight and fall than to live without hope.
author: Völsunga Saga

textLatin: A guest should be courteous when he comes to the table and sit in wary silence.
author: Hávamál, Stanza 5

textLatin: Brave men can make their own luck.
author: Norse Proverb

textLatin: Where words fail, swords prevail.
author: Viking Saying

textLatin: The foolish man thinks he will live forever if he keeps away from fighting, but old age gives him no peace even if weapons do.
author: Hávamál, Stanza 16

textLatin: It is better to stand and fight. If you run, you will only die tired.
author: Viking Proverb

textLatin: Courage is the best defense.
author: Norse Wisdom

textLatin: The wolf on the hill is not as hungry as the wolf climbing the hill.
author: Arnold Schwarzenegger

textLatin: Fear not death, for the hour of your doom is set and none may escape it.
author: Völsunga Saga

textLatin: A word to the wise is enough.
author: Plautus

textLatin: The road goes ever on and on.
author: Bilbo Baggins

textLatin: Deeds will not be less valiant because they are unpraised.
author: Aragorn

textLatin: There is some good in this world, and it is worth fighting for.
author: Samwise Gamgee

textLatin: I would rather share one lifetime with you than face all the ages of this world alone.
author: Arwen

textLatin: A man should be loyal through life to friends.
author: Hávamál, Stanza 43

textLatin: It is better to live well than to live long.
author: Norse Proverb

textLatin: Wisdom is welcome wherever it comes from.
author: Old English Proverb

textLatin: Do not speak harsh words to a guest.
author: Hávamál, Stanza 127

textLatin: The brave man well shall fight and win, though dull his blade may be.
author: Fáfnismál, Stanza 28

textLatin: Never walk away from home ahead of your axe and sword.
author: Hávamál, Stanza 38

textLatin: Evil is wrought from want of thought.
author: Old Norse Saying

textLatin: Give praise to the day at evening, to your wife when she is dead, to a weapon when tried, to ice when crossed.
author: Hávamál, Stanza 81

textLatin: Oaths should be kept.
author: Norse Value

textLatin: A man's own hand is most to be trusted.
author: Hávamál, Stanza 60

textLatin: Dawn takes you by surprise.
author: Irish Proverb

textLatin: Who seeks shall find.
author: Sophocles

textLatin: Speak your mind but ride a fast horse.
author: Western Proverb

textLatin: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold.
author: Proverbs 25:11

textLatin: Fire warms, but it also burns.
author: Old Wisdom

textLatin: One must learn by doing the thing, for though you think you know it, you have no certainty until you try.
author: Sophocles

textLatin: Better a free death than a slavish life.
author: Grettir's Saga

textLatin: Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night.
author: Sun Tzu

textLatin: Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn.
author: Laurence Binyon

textLatin: What we do in life echoes in eternity.
author: Marcus Aurelius
